channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Silicon Valley Came to Kansas Schools. That Started a Rebellion.
item.media:description: A yard sign in Wellington, Kan., where some parents and students have rebelled against a web-based education program from Summit Learning.
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.description: Public schools in Kansas rolled out a web-based learning platform backed by Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg. Now students have staged walkouts and sit-ins. Their parents have organized.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: It’s U.S. vs. World as Big Tech Faces Specter of Limiting Speech Online
item.description: Many other countries are adopting or considering stricter moderation of online speech. But they don’t have to work around the First Amendment.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG

item.title: The Interpreter: Sri Lanka Blocks Social Media, Fearing More Violence
item.media:description: Sri Lankan soldiers secured the area around St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo after a blast on Sunday.
item.description: Sri Lankan officials have a troubled relationship with social media. They have seen firsthand how quickly online hate can turn into deadly violence.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: How to Declutter and Speed Up Your Phone
item.description: If your phone is feeling a little laggy, here are some tips to clear out old apps and other things that may be slowing it down.
item.dc:creator: THORIN KLOSOWSKI

item.title: Google Employees Say They Faced Retaliation After Organizing Walkout
item.media:description: A Google employee protest in November in San Francisco. Two workers who called for a walkout over Google’s treatment of sexual harassment said they had been demoted or told that their role would change.
item.description: Two Google workers who called for an employee protest over the company’s treatment of sexual harassment said they were demoted or told their role would change.
item.dc:creator: KATE CONGER and DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: Samsung Postpones Rollout of Galaxy Fold
item.media:description: D.J. Koh, a senior executive at Samsung, announcing the new Galaxy Fold in February.
item.description: The company, the world’s largest handset maker, said it would postpone the release of the foldable smartphone after reports that the device was malfunctioning.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN and RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Tesla to Investigate Car That Appeared to Burst Into Flames in Shanghai
item.media:description: In January Tesla started construction on a huge new factory near Shanghai, its first plant outside the United States.
item.description: The fire, involving a Tesla sedan in a parking garage, left no one injured, the fire department said. The automaker said it had dispatched a team “at once.”
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: He Stopped a Global Cyberattack. Now He’s Pleading Guilty to Writing Malware.
item.media:description: Marcus Hutchins, right, a British security researcher, at the Federal Courthouse in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in 2017. He was arrested at the airport in Las Vegas earlier that year.
item.description: Marcus Hutchins, a British security researcher credited with halting a huge outbreak of ransom software in 2017, accepted United States charges over previous activity.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Bits: The Week in Tech: Do You Prefer Free Speech, or a Perfectly Clean Internet?
item.media:description: Qualcomm’s focus on 5G technology helped bring about an end to the chip maker’s battle with Apple.
item.description: Automated policing of content will never be perfect, and that leaves us facing a big question about what we want the web to be like.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE CONDLIFFE

item.title: After Social Media Bans, Militant Groups Found Ways to Remain
item.media:description: Hezbollah has been barred by the big social media companies. But the Islamist militant group has found a way to stay a step ahead online.
item.description: Hezbollah and other groups classified as terrorist organizations by the United States have changed their social media strategies to stay on Facebook, YouTube and Twitter.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: The Real Stars of the Internet
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times
item.description: The rater has become the rated.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: Uber’s Self-Driving Cars Are Valued at $7.25 Billion by Investors
item.media:description: An autonomous Volvo being developed by Uber. SoftBank, Toyota and the Japanese automaker Denso will put $1 billion toward Uber’s efforts for autonomous cars.
item.description: A billion-dollar investment is meant to prop up a money-losing unit before Uber makes its pitches ahead of a planned I.P.O.
item.dc:creator: KATE CONGER

item.title: Tesla and Elon Musk Are Given Week to Reach Accord With S.E.C.
item.media:description: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, arriving at a federal courthouse in New York for a hearing this month. The Securities and Exchange Commission sought a contempt citation, saying he had violated a settlement over his disclosure of financial information.
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.description: The adversaries told a judge they were working to resolve a dispute over Mr. Musk’s statements on financial prospects. Regulators had sought a contempt citation.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Amazon Gives Up on Chinese Domestic Shopping Business
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos, the Amazon chief executive. Amazon shoppers in China will now be able to buy only certain imported products.
item.description: The company had long struggled to gain traction in China despite operating there for more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WEISE

item.title: Samsung’s Review Phones Fail, Delivering a P.R. Nightmare
item.media:description: A model holding a Samsung Galaxy Fold smartphone at a preview event in London on Tuesday.
item.description: The company said some of the problems described in reviews of its nearly $2,000 Galaxy Fold phone might be due to the removal of a protective film from the display.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER and BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: Here’s Soylent’s New Product. It’s Food.
item.media:description: The three varietals of Soylent Squared.
item.description: The Silicon Valley food-drink of choice is now a ‘complete nutrition platform.’ The beverage plot thickens.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH and JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: I.P.O. Day for Pinterest and Zoom Ends With Shares Sharply Higher
item.media:description: Pinterest’s initial public offering on Thursday was a sign that investor demand for highly anticipated “unicorn” companies remains healthy.
item.description: Coming into these I.P.O.s, there were many questions about whether investors were willing to swallow the risk of the latest crop of tech companies.
item.dc:creator: ERIN GRIFFITH

item.title: Pinterest Prices I.P.O. at $19 a Share, for a $12.7 Billion Valuation
item.description: The shares will begin trading Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol PINS.
item.dc:creator: ERIN GRIFFITH

item.title: Foxconn’s Deal With Wisconsin Should Be Revised, Gov. Tony Evers Says
item.media:description: “The present contract deals with a situation that no longer exists,” Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin said on Wednesday.
item.description: Governor Evers, citing an “unreal expectation” of job creation, wants a new agreement with the Taiwanese electronic giant to build a $10 billion plant.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY HSU

item.title: Tech We’re Using: The Must-Have When Reporting on Disasters: A Satellite Phone
item.media:description: Thomas Fuller's reliance on a satellite phone in Southeast Asia continued when he became chief of The New York Times's San Francisco bureau and reported on wildfires.
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.description: Thomas Fuller, San Francisco bureau chief, knows you cannot rely on cell networks during earthquakes, wildfires and other breaking news catastrophes.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Tech Fix: Uber vs. Lyft: Which Ride-Hailing App Is Better?
item.description: Here’s a comprehensive comparison of the two services to help you choose your go-to app for hitching rides.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: The Man Who Made Your iPhone Wants to Run Taiwan. A Sea Goddess Backs Him, He Says.
item.media:description: Mr. Gou said he would seek the nomination of Taiwan’s opposition Kuomintang party on Wednesday.
item.description: The entrance into the presidential race by the billionaire Terry Gou shakes up Taiwan’s political playing field and draws into sharp focus its strained relations with China.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: As Netflix Contends With More Rivals, Hulu Stands Out
item.media:description: Reed Hastings, Netflix’s founder and chief executive, in Barcelona, Spain.
item.description: With 148 million subscribers and a value of $157 billion, Netflix is the leader in streaming. But Hulu, now controlled by Disney, has something Netflix doesn’t: ads. And they are worth a lot.
item.dc:creator: EDMUND LEE

item.title: Apple and Qualcomm Settle All Disputes Worldwide
item.media:description: Just as a trial had begun in a federal courtroom in San Diego over a suit Apple had filed against Qualcomm, the two companies said they had essentially made up.
item.description: Apple and Qualcomm said they had agreed to dismiss all litigation between them worldwide.
item.dc:creator: DON CLARK and DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: in her words: #WhatsMyName Stresses Safety for Uber Riders
item.description: A South Carolina student was murdered after getting into a car she mistook for her Uber, underscoring the safety risks of ride-hailing apps.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: YouTube Fact-Checks the Fire at Notre-Dame With Facts About ... 9/11
item.media:description: Firefighters doused flames billowing from the roof at Notre-Dame cathedral on Monday.
item.description: The company said that a misguided algorithm paired live footage of the blaze in Paris with information about the 2001 terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: Square Feet: A New Recruitment Tool for Construction: The Joystick
item.media:description: Kraemer Trucking and Excavating in Cold Spring, Minn., in a partnership with Ziegler Cat, took a trailer of simulators — a bulldozer, a road grader and an excavator — to a local high school this month.
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.description: To help attract a generation that grew up playing video games, the construction industry has turned to simulators that replicate jobs done by heavy equipment.
item.dc:creator: JASON M. BAILEY

item.title: The New New World: Donald Trump, China Savior? Some Chinese Say Yes
item.description: Business leaders and intellectuals say one of Beijing’s toughest critics could force the country to change. Still needed: voices of support from the inside.
item.dc:creator: LI YUAN

item.title: Wheels: High-Tech Collision Warnings, No Matter How Smart Your Car Is
item.description: “This can be a great way to get the safety benefit of crash-avoidance technology at a reduced cost compared to a new car,” said the author of a safety study.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER JENSEN
